dc:description:
NUDCD3 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive severe combined immunodeficiency and Omenn syndrome in 2024 (Chen, R. et al., PMID: 38787962). Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) occurs due to abnormal lymphocyte function, specifically T-cells and B-cells, thus resulting in increased susceptibility to infection. Omenn syndrome is a related disorder in which individuals typically have inflammation of the skin and viscera along with SCID-like lymphocyte abnormalities. A single homozygous hypomorphic missense variant, p.G52D, has been reported in 4 unrelated families of South Asian descent with a shared ancestral haplotype, suggesting it is likely a founder variant (PMID: 38787962). Two of the families were clinically described in previous publications (PMID: 15964782, 27577878).  NUDCD3-related SCID and Omenn syndrome are characterized by erythroderma, alopecia, viral and bacterial infections, increased eosinophils, hyperIgE, hepatomegaly, abnormal leukocyte and lymphocyte counts, reduced or absent B cells, and T-cell abnormalities. There is inter- and intra-familial phenotypic variability. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of function; however, more research is needed to establish the disease mechanism. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence, including in vitro functional assays, expression studies, and animal models (PMIDs: 38787962). NUDCD3 was shown to disrupt V(D)J recombination leading to abnormal T and B cell development in both in vitro and in vivo studies. Additionally, it was shown that NUDCD3 plays a key role in the redistribution of RAG1 from nucleoli, which is known to be necessary for RAG recombinase function. 

In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. The experimental evidence was determined to be robust even with only a single variant being reporting in multiple consanguineous families from the same ethnic background; it has not been reported to occur in another population, and has not been replicated overtime. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the ClinGen SCID-CID GCEP on 04/17/2025 as per SOP v11.
curationReasonDescription: There was robust experimental data to support the association of NUDCD3 with SCID/Omenn syndrome, however, there has only been a single, likely founder, variant reported in individuals and it has not been replicated over time. Therefore, the SCID-CID Gene Curation Expert Panel elected to leave the classification at Limited to give enough time for additional individuals to be reported.

evidence.dc:description: The variant is homozygous due to consanguinity, and a recurrent variant among individuals with a shared ancestral haplotype.
See Patient 3.3 for description of functional data

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2.1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Elevated eosinophils (6000 per microliter)
Positive Enterococcus, Coagulase-negative Staphylococci
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Whole Exome Sequencing (PMID: 27577878, Patient ID 108.1), however, at the time the gene was reported as a potential novel gene. The HGNC gene symbol had not yet been approved as NUDCD3.

evidence.dc:description: The variant is homozygous due to consanguinity, and a recurrent variant among individuals with a shared ancestral haplotype.
See patient 3.3 for description of functional data

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1.1
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Southern blot analysis of Artemis in the patient was normal, while a region of 1kb at the 5' region of Rag1 and Rag2 genes was investigated by sequencing without finding any abnormalities. Results showed RAG1 heterozygous polymorphism G858A, normal RAG2, Artemis normal (PMID 15964782).

evidence.dc:description: The variant is homozygous due to consanguinity, and a recurrent variant among individuals with a shared ancestral haplotype.
See Patient 3.3 for description of functional data

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 4.1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Elevated eosinophils (14300 per microliter) 
Elevated absolute lymphocyte count (18210 per microliter)
Normal IgG, IgA, IgM
High proportion of activated T cells and digoclonal T cells

evidence.rdfs:label: Chen Family 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Eosinophils 5800 per microliter
Lymph node biopsy showing absence of germinal centers and abundant T cells

evidence.dc:description: The variant is homozygous due to consanguinity

Coimmunoprecipitation experiments of tagged mutant cells transfected with G52D into HEK293 cells demonstrated reduced homodimerization suggesting disruption of specific function of the protein (Fig 1F).

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 3.3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Eosinophils identified (15300 per microliter) 
Leathery skin rash
HLA-DR+ T: 85%

evidence.dc:description:
Immunoglobulin production was preserved in Nudcd3Hom mice, with slightly increased immunoglobulin M (IgM) and IgG2b and markedly increased IgE as is also seen in mice bearing Rag1R972Q/R972Q and Rag2R229Q/R229Q variants and in human patients with OS, but this was not directly compared to the NUDCD3 G52D patients. G52D patients had overall normal immunoglobulin levels, however, it varied among the families. 

Both T and B cell development are perturbed in Nudcd3 G52D mice, although to a lesser degree
than that observed in human NUDCD3 G52D patients or in published mouse models of hypomorphic RAG deficiency, especially in the case of B cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: NUDC3 G52D homozygous mice

evidence.dc:description:
Co-transfection of patient and control fibroblasts with RAG1, RAG2, and a synthetic substrate for RAG recombination, which could be detected by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of the rearranged product. In this preliminary screen, where the expression of each transfected component could not be assessed at single-cell level, NUDCD3 G52D patient cells nonetheless appeared highly defective in supporting RAG-dependent recombination. 

Assessment of endogenous V(D)J rearrangement using a mouse pre-B cell line, 103/BCL2, demonstrated NUDCD3 dependence. This process can be triggered by a shift in temperature
and detected by quantitative PCR for kappa-deleting recombination excision circles (KRECs). Nudcd3 expression had been partially knocked down by small interfering RNA (siRNA) transfection which demonstrated, in vivo, that this resulted in defective V(D)J recombination
evidence.rdfs:label: Co-transfection with RAG1/RAG2 and substrate

evidence.dc:description:
Drastic abnormalities in the distribution of circulating lymphocyte subsets were readily observed in patients with OS by flow cytometry, including the complete lack of B cells and naïve T cells. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed widely divergent distribution across the 39 cell subpopulations annotated (32 lymphoid and seven myeloid), including within each of the mutation groups. 
Analysis of T-cell receptor usage within single-cell transcriptomic data revealed reduced diversity and expanded clonotype size in patients with OS, as expected (Fig. 2D and fig. S7A). Confirmed the previously noted skewing of the RAG1/2-deficient TCR repertoire toward the use of TRA gene segments near the 3′ end of the Vα locus and the 5′ end of the Jα locus (Fig. 2E), a pattern that was reproduced in the T cells of patients with NUDCD3 G52D (Fig. 2E). These proximal TRA gene segments are preferentially recombined at the start of the DP stage of thymocyte development. The predominance of proximal Vα and Jα gene segment usage therefore implied that NUDCD3 G52D T-cells were unable to execute repeated rounds of V(D)J recombination during their development, just as in RAG Omenn T cells. These data suggested that there was a primary defect in V(D)J recombination associated with homozygosity for the NUDCD3 G52D variant.
evidence.rdfs:label: Single cell RNA seq

evidence.dc:description:
There is an incomplete block in Nudcd3Hom mouse thymocyte development at stages where V(D)J recombination occurs.  Surface marker expression showed highly statistically significant excess of CD4−CD8− double-negative (DN) thymocytes. Specifically, the expansion of DN3a and DP1 implies a direct effect of Nudcd3Hom on V(D)J recombination rather than a primary impairment of survival that shortens the time available for V(D)J recombination. 

In isolated splenocytes, Nudcd3Hom mice showed strongly skewed Tra gene usage toward V segments from the 3′ end of the V locus and J segments from the 5′ end of the J locus and the absence of a similar effect for Trb or Ig gene segments. Nudcd3Hom mice had fewer nonproductive Trb chain rearrangements than WT, indicating an unproductive recombination is followed by a successful second round of recombination, ensuring T cell survival. 

Flow cytometry showed relative accumulation of IgM−IgD− (fraction D) pre-B cells and a trend toward a reduction in mature IgM+IgD+ B cells (fraction F) but no effect on pro-B cell populations (fractions A to C) (fig. S13, A to D). Thus, both T and B cell development are perturbed in Nudcd3G52D mice, although to a lesser degree than that observed in human NUDCD3G52D patients or in published mouse models of hypomorphic RAG deficiency, especially in the case of B cells. Mixed bone marrow chimera experiments confirm the cell-intrinsic nature of both B and T cell abnormalities in the Nudcd3Hom mouse.
evidence.rdfs:label: Lymphocyte development in vivo

evidence.dc:description: Redistribution of RAG1 from nucleoli, known to be necessary for its recombinase function, not only is RAG2 dependent but also requires a specific activity of NUDCD3 that the G52D allele lacks as demonstrated in HEK293T NUDCD3-knockdown cells. Mislocalization of RAG1 in NUDCD3-deficient RAG2-cotransfected cells was accompanied by an overall increase in RAG1 protein expression as assessed by immunoblotting.
evidence.rdfs:label: In vitro recombination reporter assay and Immunofluorescence

evidence.dc:description: Reduced protein expression of NUDCD3 in primary patient dermal fibroblasts compared with controls, however equivalent mRNA expression to controls, suggesting hypomorphic behavior of the variant allele
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunoblot in patient cells
